Graphical abstract Herein, we report the aerobic oxidation of several bio-oils (pyrolysis and microwave) derived from Kraft lignin using oxovanadium complex catalyst, (HQ)2Vv(O)(O i Pr) (HQ=8-oxyquinoline) (2), ionic liquid (IL)-tagged oxovanadium complex, PF6-IL-salen-VIV(O) (3) (PF6 =hexafluorophosphate) and copper catalyst CuX/TEMPO/2,6-lutidine (4) [X=OTf, trifluoro-methanesulfonate), Cl; TEMPO=2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl]. Cleavage of some lignin linkages and reduced phenolic content were observed by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy, FT-IR and 1D/2D GC/MS analysis. Catalyst 2 oxidized chloroform extracts of the microwave bio-oil more extensively than those from the pyrolysis bio-oil although reactivity trends were similar. With catalyst 3 in [MMIM][MeOSO3], the phenolic conversion was modest compared with the increase in carboxyl and decrease in aliphatic OH groups. IR spectra were consistent with phenol oxidation to quinone-type structures. In contrast, copper catalyst 4 showed formation of high molecular weight compounds after oxidation, likely resulting from radical recombination. Comparison of reactivity between the different types of lignin-derived bio-oils is also discussed. Keywords Lignin Oxidation Bio-oil Catalysis Ionic liquids Vanadium 1 Introduction Rapid depletion of petroleum and increasing environmental concerns are driving the exploration of new alternatives for petrochemicals. Lignocellulosic biomass is a promising candidate for the production of chemicals and materials [1]. It is constituted primarily of hemicellulose, cellulose and lignin; the latter is the most abundant non-food and renewable aromatic-containing macromolecule on Earth [2]. Despite the large production of lignin in the pulp and paper industry, this material has a limited usage, mostly as a low-grade fuel. Pyrolysis can be used to liquefy lignin, facilitating transportation and storage and potentially increasing its economic value. In this process, lignin is heated rapidly between 500 and 700°C in the absence of oxygen to produce a liquid bio-oil [3]. Pyrolysis of lignin also decreases the molecular weight through cleavage of β-O-4 linkages (Fig. 1 ) [4]. In a complementary technique, microwave reactors are used to produce bio-oils, avoiding temperature gradients and formation of the char by-product obtained from thermal heating [5]. Pyrolysis and microwave bio-oils have a high water and acid content [6] that triggers their decomposition through radical polymerization, generating an intractable mixture [7]. Due to this instability, valorization of lignin bio-oils has been limited to hydrodeoxygenation [8], catalytic pyrolysis [9], zeolite cracking [10] and steam-reforming [11], among others. Oxidation using inexpensive base metal catalysts and air is an attractive approach for the depolymerization of lignin [12]. However, oxidation of bio-oils to produce chemicals is scarce in the literature. Xu et al. oxidized bio-oils using ozone to convert the aldehyde content into acids that could then be esterified to improve the fuel properties [13]. Boateng et al. reported the production of smaller monomers from pyrolytic lignin using transition metal complexes such as copper, manganese, vanadium and iron [14]. Unfortunately, no further details of this work have yet appeared in the literature. Baker et al. reported several oxovanadium (eg., 1 and 2) and copper/TEMPO/pyridine [TEMPO=2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl] (4) catalysts for the selective cleavage of lignin models using air as terminal oxidant (Fig. 2 ) [15]. Control over CC and CH bond cleavage was achieved using different solvents and oxovanadium(V) catalysts [16]. In one example, cleavage of phenoxyethanol lignin models, containing the β-O-4 linkage (the most abundant in hardwoods), afforded mainly ketone and phenol by CH bond cleavage, followed by CC bond cleavage of the ketone intermediate (Scheme 1 ) [17]. In contrast, the Cu/TEMPO catalyst 4, with the addition of 2,6-lutidine, effected the selective CC bond cleavage of β-O-4 and β-1 lignin models, in spite of the poor carbon balance of these reactions [16a,b]. Recently, we showed that 1 and 2 are efficient catalysts for reducing the molecular weight of organosolv lignin, retaining the reactivity observed in lignin models [18]. As a solvent for bio-based transformations, ionic liquids (ILs) have the advantage of dissolving lignocellulosic biomass and allowing for fractionation into cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin components [19a]. Singer and co-workers reported that ionic liquid-tagged CoIII(salen) complex could be used as a catalyst with air/oxygen in ILs to selectively oxidize lignin model compound veratryl alcohol to veratryl aldehyde, allowing recycling of the catalyst and ionic liquid [19b]. Kervinen et al. reported an aerobic oxidation of veratryl alcohol to an aldehyde in aqueous media using Co(salen) complexes with various substituents [19c]. Zakzeski et al. reported that transition metal cobalt salts have shown better activity compared to Co(salen) and Co(porphryin) catalysts for the oxidation of lignin model compounds, Alcell lignin, and soda lignin in ionic liquids [19d]. A second advantage of ILs is their compatibility with microwave heating. It is known that microwave irradiation triggers heating by two main mechanisms – dipolar polarization and ionic conduction [19e]. Due to their ionic nature, ILs allow for highly effective interactions with microwave energy for accelerated reaction times and high product yields [19f]. Herein, we report the catalytic oxidation of pyrolysis and microwave bio-oils with oxovanadium -complex 2, IL-tagged 3 and Cu/TEMPO/lutidine catalyst 4 (Fig. 2) using air as the terminal oxidant. The oxidized fractions were analyzed using IR and multinuclear NMR spectroscopy (1H, 13C UDEFT, and 31P of derived phosphite esters) and GC/MS experiments. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 General considerations 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra were obtained at room temperature on Bruker AV300MHz, AV400MHz or AV500MHz spectrometers with chemical shifts (δ) referenced to the residual solvent signal. Deuterated solvents were purchased from Cambridge Isotope Laboratories and dried with molecular sieves. Acetonitrile (CH3CN), chloroform (CHCl3), dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), diethyl ether (Et2O), ethanol (EtOH), tetrahydrofuran (THF), dimethylformamide (DMF), ethyl acetate (EtOAc), chromium(III) tris(acetylacetonate), cyclohexanol, 2-chloro-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaphospholane (TMDP), N,N-diisopropylethylamine (DIPEA), CuCl, Cu(OTf)2 (OTf=trifluoromethanesulfonate), TEMPO, 2,6-lutidine and VO(acac)2 were purchased from Sigma Aldrich or Fisher Scientific and used without further purification. 1-Ethyl-3-methylimidazolium acetate, [EMIM][OAc], was purchased from Sigma Aldrich and dried under vacuum at 80°C for 6–8h prior to use. 1,3-Dimethylimidazolium methyl sulfate, [MMIM][MeOSO3], was synthesized in our laboratories according to literature procedures [20]. Microwave and pyrolysis bio-oils were prepared by our collaborators at École Polytechnique and Western University, respectively, according to their reported procedures [5,21]. Oxygen was purchased from Linde Canada. Catalyst 2 was synthesized according to the published procedure [16d]. Quantitative 31P NMR spectroscopy experiments were carried out following the reported procedure [22]. In order to prepare phosphitylation experiments, bio-oil samples were extracted with CHCl3 or diethyl ether to reduce the water content. Solvents were then evaporated using a rotary evaporator followed by high vacuum. Under nitrogen atmosphere, 25mg of bio-oil or the oxidized bio-oil residue was dissolved in 1.6:1 (v/v) of pyridine/CDCl3 (500μL) then 50μL of TMDP and 5μL of cyclohexanol were added to the solution. The reaction mixture was stirred for 10min at room temperature and then transferred to a sealed screw-cap NMR tube. The spectrum was acquired using an inverse-gated decoupling pulse sequence, with a 90° pulse angle, 25s pulse delay and 256 scans when AV500 MHZ was used. Chromium(III) tris(acetylacetonate) and cyclohexanol were used as relaxation reagent and internal standard, respectively. The spectra were calibrated using the internal standard chemical shift at 145.2ppm. All spectra were processed using TopSpin 3.0. The 13C NMR spectra (75.5MHz) were recorded using the UDEFT (uniform driven equilibrium Fourier transform) sequence which allows for recording 1D 13C{1H} spectra devoid of heteronuclear NOE (nuclear Overhauser effect) [23]. The carbon 90° pulses were equal to 13.2μs and the carbon sweep-width was set to 300ppm. The refocusing pulse was a 2ms composite smoothed chirp and the inversion pulse was a 500μs smoothed chirp. The 1H decoupling pulse of the WALTZ 16 sequence was set to a 100μs, whereas the 1H adiabatic decoupling pulse was a 1.5ms 20KHz smoothed chirp phase-cycled according to the P5M4 supercycle. For 13C UDEFT experiments, the carbon acquisition time was set to 180ms and 8K complex points were recorded. Linear prediction was used to increase the number of points from 64 to 131K complex points. An exponential multiplication using a 4 or 5Hz line broadening was applied before Fourier transformation. GC/MS analysis was obtained using a Hewlett Packard 6890 GC system equipped with a Hewlett Packard 5973 mass selective detector or in a Varian CP-3800 chromatograph equipped with FID and MS detectors. Star 6.41 chromatography and NIST 98 MS Library were used to process the chromatogram and identify the compounds corresponding to observed peaks at specific retention times respectively. The 2D-GC/MS was conducted using a LECO Pegasus® 4D GCxGC-TOFMS with a Gerstel MPS2®Autosampler with 10μL syringe and ChromaTOF® data acquisition software was used to collect the chromatograms. The primary column was RTX-5 10m×150μm, 0.18μm film, and secondary column was DB1701, 1m×100μm, 0.10μm film. The primary oven temperature system was 40°C–4min, 5°/min to 225°C, hold 5min, total time 46min and secondary oven temperature system was 20°C offset from primary oven, track primary oven program. The mass spectrometry parameters were setup as follows: acquisition range, 29–350amu; rate, 200spectra/sec; source temperature, 250°C; transfer line temperature, 250°C. In a 10mL scintillation vial, 20mg of bio-oil was diluted in 2mL of acetonitrile, then passed through a small pipette containing glass wool and silica gel. From this solution, 100μL of the filtrate was further diluted with 500μL of acetonitrile to give a new concentration of ca. 1.5mg/mL (some of the bio-oil was lost in the filtration process). The GC/MS experiment was performed on this final sample. The IR spectra were acquired on a Bruker Alpha FT-IR fitted with universal sampling module using a KBr disc. For the bio-oil samples, a Bruker Platinum ATR fitted with single reflection diamond ATR crystal was used to record the IR spectrum of the dry samples. High-resolution mass spectra (ESI-HRMS) were recorded in positive and negative ion modes in a Bruker MicroToF Focus orthogonal ESI-TOF. Elemental analysis was obtained using a Perkin Elmer 2400 series II CHN elemental analyzer. The CEM Microwave®™ Synthesis System, Discover SP, was used for the catalytic oxidation reactions of pyrolysis bio-oil in ionic liquids. The Discover SP System consists of continuous microwave delivery system (2450MHz magnetron frequency) with operator selectable power output (0–300W). It is equipped with infrared temperature control system (0–300°C), electromagnetic adjustable speed stirring and air-cooling. 2.2 Synthesis of catalyst 3 Synthesis of the ionic ligand (PF6-IL-salen) was performed according to a literature procedure [24]. VO(acac)2 (0.186g, 0.701mmol) was dissolved in 5mL anhydrous ethanol while stirring at room temperature. This solution was added dropwise to the solution of IL-salen ligand (0.500g, 0.670mmol) in anhydrous ethanol (15mL) while stirring and heating at 75°C. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 4h and a green precipitate was formed. The resulting green solid was filtered under reduced pressure and washed with cold ethanol. The green precipitate was dried under high vacuum with heating at 60°C to afford 0.455g (84%) of material. Found; C, 39.26%; H, 3.52%; N, 10.18%. 2.3 General procedure for aerobic catalytic oxidation of bio-oils using 2 For the microwave bio-oil, 100mg was transferred to a 50mL round bottom flask equipped with a reflux condenser containing 10wt% of 2 and 2.5wt% of triethylamine in ethyl acetate (7mL) under air. The reaction mixture was heated in an oil bath at 100°C with constant stirring. After 24h, the reaction was cooled to room temperature and the solvent was removed in a rotary evaporator to give an insoluble oily residue. An aliquot of the reaction residue was dissolved in DMSO-d 6 (1mL) for the 1H, 13C UDEFT and HSQC NMR experiments. For the 31P NMR experiments, another aliquot of the oily residue was extracted with chloroform to reduce any residual water content. The CHCl3 was removed in a rotary evaporator to give an oily residue. A 20mg aliquot of this residue was transferred to a dry box, then the phosphitylation reaction was performed and the sample was examined by 31P NMR spectroscopy. For the pyrolysis bio-oil, the same procedure as above was followed except that the sample was extracted with chloroform prior to oxidation, dried with MgSO4 and purified under high vacuum. 2.4 General procedure for the aerobic catalytic oxidation of bio-oil using 3 The bio-oil was heated at 80°C under vacuum for 6–8h to remove any residual water. The dry bio-oil (100mg) was transferred to a round bottom flask and 2mL of ionic liquid was added with constant stirring at 80°C for 20–30min to allow the dissolution of the bio-oil. While maintaining the solution at 80°C, 10wt% of catalyst 3 and 10wt% of DIPEA were added to the bio-oil ionic liquid solution. Either [EMIM][OAc] or [MMIM][MeOSO3] ionic liquids were used as solvents for these reactions. The reaction mixture was transferred to a round bottom flask and then placed in the cavity of the microwave reactor. A water condenser and gas-sparger tube were fitted to the round bottom flask and pure oxygen was bubbled continuously into the reaction mixture. The open vessel method and the dynamic mode of operation of the microwave were used for the reactions. All reactions in the microwave reactor were maintained at 80°C, maximum power of 200W, 4h of reaction time and medium stirring speed. The reaction mixture was then extracted with Et2O or THF to separate the organic-soluble products from the ionic liquid and the catalyst. Solvent extraction was carried out using 5×10mL allowing 30–40min interval between each extraction. The organic layer was filtered through a pipette plugged with glass wool. The organic layers were combined and the solvent was evaporated. The oily residue obtained was further dried at 70°C under vacuum for 4h. For the recycling studies, the bio-oil crude products after the oxidation with catalyst 3 in [EMIM][OAc] were extracted with THF (5×10mL) leaving the catalyst in the ionic liquid phase. A new load of fresh bio-oil (100mg) was dissolved in THF and added to the catalyst/IL solution. The THF was then removed under vacuum. The resulting mixture was transferred to a microwave reactor and the oxidation was carried out using the same procedure as described above. The crude mixture was extracted with THF (5×10mL) and the solvent was removed by evaporation. The residue obtained was dried under vacuum at 70°C for 4h prior to the 31P NMR analysis. This procedure was repeated for two additional cycles. 2.5 General procedure for aerobic catalytic oxidation of bio-oil using 4 with 2,6-lutidine The bio-oil (100mg) was transferred to a thick-walled 50mL Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon stopcock containing [Cu(OTf)]2·toluene (20mg, 0.044mmol), TEMPO (6mg, 0.04mmol) and 2,6-lutidine (45uL, 0.39mmol) in DMF (7mL) under air. Oxygen was bubbled into the reaction mixture through a needle for 2min and the reactor was sealed. The reaction mixture was heated at 100°C with constant stirring. After 48h, the reaction was cooled to room temperature and the solvent was removed in vacuo. To an aliquot of the reaction mixture, DMSO-d 6 (1mL) was added and filtered through glass wool and examined by NMR experiments. Further analysis was performed using 2D GC/MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of microwave and pyrolysis bio-oils The pyrolysis bio-oil was soluble in diethyl ether, 88% (w/w), and completely soluble in THF. The microwave bio-oil was completely soluble in diethyl ether. 1H NMR spectra of the microwave and pyrolysis bio-oils revealed peaks corresponding to CH3 (0.5–1.5ppm), CH2 (1.7–2.4ppm), methoxy (3.5–4.2ppm), and aromatic protons (6.0–7.5ppm). NMR assignments were based on literature values [25]. The bio-oils were also analyzed using 13C{1H} UDEFT which allows for the characterization of lignin at shorter acquisition times. The microwave bio-oil does not contain syringyl C1 units at 125ppm and C3, C5 at 151ppm, respectively (Scheme 2 ). The lower intensity for the signals for Cγ in β-5 and β-O-4 at62-65ppm and Cγ in β-O-4 (withoutCαO) at57-61ppm, respectively, are in agreement with the lower concentration (vs. lignin) of these linkages for the microwave and pyrolysis bio-oils. Phosphitylation of lignin residues has been shown to be a useful tool for characterizing the various types of aromatic, aliphatic and carboxylic acid OH bonds (Fig. 1, Scheme 2). 31P NMR spectrum of the microwave bio-oil revealed a higher content of all the lignin linkages compared with the pyrolysis bio-oil except for the aliphatic and carboxylic hydroxyls (Fig. 3 ). The 2D GC/MS (two columns connected in series) shows the complexity of the bio-oil composition (Fig. 4 ) with up to 65 different compounds identified, most of which are phenolics (see Supplementary information). 3.2 Catalytic aerobic oxidation of bio-oils with catalyst 2 The aerobic oxidation was carried out using 10wt% of 2 and 2.5wt% of triethylamine in ethyl acetate (100°C, 24h). The residue after catalysis was extracted with diethylether to give 39% (w/w) for the microwave and 76% (w/w) for the pyrolysis bio-oils. The 1H NMR spectrum of the microwave bio-oil after oxidation showed new resonances in both the aromatic (6.8–7.5) and acyl ((8.5–9) regions (Figs. 5 and S1). Although the 1H NMR spectrum of the chloroform soluble pyrolysis bio-oil fraction was broadened due to catalyst contamination, several new acyl and aromatic resonances were also apparent in this oxidized sample (Fig. S2). The 13C UDEFT NMR spectrum of the microwave bio-oil after oxidation shows a reduction in the C3/C4 guaiacyl and C3/C5 syringyl units (142–155ppm) and a reduction in the C1 resonances for guaiacyl, syringyl and hydroxyphenyl, C4 for syringyl, and C2/6 for hydroxyphenyl units (123-140ppm; Fig. 6 ). New signals appeared at 138.5ppm and 136.0ppm characteristic of aldehydes and carboxylic acids. Guaiacyl units involved in ether linkages C5 at 119ppm and phenolics at 145ppm significantly decreased in intensity. The 13C UDEFT NMR spectrum of the pyrolysis bio-oil after the oxidation (Fig. S5) shows a lower production of aldehydes and acids compared with the oxidized microwave bio-oil. Guaiacyl (C5) units at 119ppm and 145ppm remain intact while the aromatic regions at 142–155ppm and123–140ppm showed a smaller decrease (vs. microwave bio-oil). The 31P NMR spectrum of the microwave bio-oil shows that the guaiacyl, catechol, and p-hydroxyl phenyl regions were significantly reduced upon oxidation (Table 1 ). The resonances corresponding to the substituted guaiacyl region (140–145ppm) were reduced almost completely after oxidation. After oxidation, the guaiacyl units were reduced by approximately 70%, catechol by 88%, p-hydroxyphenyl by 82%, and substituted guaiacyl by 74%, respectively. The pyrolysis bio-oil followed a similar trend but to a lesser extent (Fig. S8). Since the 31P NMR analysis are quantifications of the concentration of only hydroxyl lignin-containing linkages in an aliquot, the mass balance of the reaction after oxidation can be estimated as the weight of solid residue obtained once the solvent is removed. For catalyst 2, the weight of the solid residue after the oxidation averaged from 70 to 83% (w/w). The GC/MS of the pyrolysis bio-oil after oxidation (Fig. S14) showed complete disappearance of 4-allyl-2-methoxyphenol (7.12min) and new unidentified peaks at higher molecular weights with molecular ions of 207.1 m/z (16.18min), 267.0 m/z (18.36min), 206.8 m/z (18.50min), 207.0 m/z (18.92min), 206.9 m/z (18.89min). The GC/MS of microwave bio-oil showed significant differences before and after catalysis (Figs. S13, S15). Less 3-methylphenol and guaiacol were observed vs. pyrolysis bio-oil and total disappearance of 4-allyl-2-methoxyphenol and 3-methoxyacetophenone was seen after oxidation. New products observed included 3-hydroxy-4-methoxyacetophenone and unidentified higher molecular weight compounds with molecular ions of 124.0 m/z and 244.1 m/z (10.45min). 3.3 Catalytic aerobic oxidation of pyrolysis bio-oil with catalyst 3 With IL-tagged catalyst 3 we have the potential for separating the oxidized bio-oil from the catalyst by conducting the reaction in ionic liquid solvent. The amount of material extracted from the oxidized bio-oil reaction depends on the type of ionic liquid used as a solvent. For [EMIM][OAc], 15% (w/w) of the oxidized bio-oil sample was extracted using diethylether while 48% (w/w) was extracted using THF. Extraction is improved with [MMIM][MeOSO3] for which 21% (w/w) of the soluble residue was extracted using diethyl ether and 56% (w/w) with THF. The ether fraction of the pyrolysis bio-oil oxidized using catalyst 3/[EMIM][OAc] showed changes as indicated by 1H NMR spectroscopy (Fig. S3). For the oxidized fraction using [MMIM][MeOSO3] as a solvent, the NMR resonances were broadened, presumably due to paramagnetic catalyst contamination (Fig. S4). Nonetheless, changes in the spectrum were apparent after oxidation as confirmed below. The 13C UDEFT NMR spectrum of the ether fraction after oxidation using catalyst 3 in [MMIM][MeOSO3] showed that minor peaks due to β-O-4 and other aliphatic linkages disappeared upon oxidation along with major aromatic resonances (Fig. 7 ). 31P NMR spectra of the phosphite esters derived from the ether-soluble fraction of pyrolysis bio-oil showed significant changes upon oxidation (Table 2 ). The fraction recovered from both ionic liquid media ([EMIM][OAc] and [MMIM][[MeOSO3]) after oxidation using catalyst 3 reveals that reduction of catechol (138–139ppm), guaiacyl phenolics (139–140ppm), and aliphatic hydroxyl groups (145.5–150.0ppm) are accompanied by increases in carboxylic OH (133.6–136.6ppm) (Figs. S9, S10). After the oxidation in [EMIM][OAc] using catalyst 3, the guaiacyl units were reduced by approximately 91%, the catechol units by 95%, the p-hydroxylphenyl units by 85%, and the C5 substituted condensed phenolic units by 87%, respectively. As indicated previously, carboxyl OH (CH) increased significantly in the oxidized pyrolysis bio-oil (Table 2). Increased conversion in [EMIM][OAc] showed the performance of the catalytic system depends on the type of IL solvent used for oxidation reaction. GC/MS analysis of the ether soluble fraction of oxidized pyrolysis bio-oil in [EMIM][OAc] confirmed decrease of phenolics and formation of non-phenolic products such as 1-ethyl-4-methoxybenzene, 3,4-methylenedioxy-anisole and 4-acetoxy-3-methoxyacetophenone (Fig. S16a). FT-IR analysis performed on the bio-oil oxidized with catalyst 3/[EMIM][[OAc], showed that the phenolic–OH band disappeared while a CO band appeared at 1672cm−1 consistent with a quinone-type structure (Fig. S19). Observations from the FT-IR spectra that showed disappearance/decrease of phenolic/alcohol hydroxyl groups and appearance of a carbonyl group are thus in agreement with the 31P NMR data in Table 2. Determination of the carbon mass balance can be estimated by subtraction of the weight of insoluble solids by-products but detailed analysis is complicated by formation of CO2 and other volatiles such as formic acid. Using solvent fractionation, for example, 65–75% (w/w) of the oxidized bio-oil could be recovered from the crude reaction mixture. For the ionic liquid reactions complications also arise from distribution of the products between the extraction solvent and ionic liquid. While we did not perform a detailed analysis of product yield dependence on the nature of the ionic liquid, we noted that the [MeOSO3]-based IL extracted the oxidation products more efficiently than did the [OAc]-based IL perhaps as the hydrogen-bond basicity (β) is lower for the former [26,27]. Consequently, the products are less strongly hydrogen-bonded in [MMIM][MeOSO3] and hence are more easily extracted into organic solvents (eg., diethyl ether and THF). As our determination of the product yield is derived primarily from the 31P NMR spectra of the derived phosphite esters, increased solubility of the [OAc]-based IL in diethylether further complicates its comparison with the less ether-soluble [MeOSO3]-based IL. The IR spectra, however, indicate more extensive conversion of the phenolic OH using the [OAc]-based IL. Recycling of the catalyst 3/[EMIM][OAc] system was carried out and 31P NMR spectra of the oxidized bio-oil for three cycles was recorded (Fig. S21). In the 31P NMR spectrum of oxidized bio-oil, the appearance of carboxylic OH (133.6–136.6ppm) and disappearance of condensed phenolic units (140.2–144.5ppm) was consistently observed over three cycles revealing that the catalyst in ionic liquid retained its catalytic activity. 3.4 Copper catalyst Copper salts with TEMPO have been demonstrated as powerful oxidation catalysts for alcohols and disassembly of lignin models [16a,b]. The pyrolysis bio-oil was heated with CuX/TEMPO (X=Cl, OTf) catalyst in the presence of excess 2,6-lutidine in DMF at 100°C for 48h. The 1H NMR spectrum revealed several sharp aromatic peaks in the region between 6.7ppm to 8.89ppm (Fig. S11). In particular, there were four to six singlets in the region between 9.70ppm to 10.30ppm corresponding to aromatic aldehydes and acids. In addition, new resonances such as a triplet at 5.30ppm (J =5.5Hz) and a doublet at 4.6ppm (J =7.0Hz) appeared as products after the oxidation. Formation of aromatic aldehydes and acids is consistent with the oxidation of pyrolysis bio-oils. We did not see any significant difference using either CuCl or CuOTf as the catalyst precursor. Analysis of the lignin-derived bio-oil using 2D-GC/MS identified 44 compounds that appeared after oxidation with CuOTf/TEMPO/lutidine catalyst 4 (Fig. 8 ). Although the number of higher molecular weight compounds (37–44) decreased upon oxidation, no evidence of low molecular weight quinones was obtained, suggesting oligomerization of these species as seen previously with lignin models using this catalyst system [16b]. 4 Conclusions Oxidation of lignin-derived bio-oils affords decreased colour, suggesting conversion of some portion of the pyrolytic lignin fraction. Although we were unable to quantify the products formed, 31P NMR spectra of derived phosphites gave clear evidence for oxidation of phenolics, presumably to quinones [28]. Several differences were observed depending on the catalyst and the type of bio-oil. Using catalyst 2, chloroform extracts of the microwave bio-oil were more reactive than those from the pyrolysis bio-oil although reactivity trends were similar. For the latter, a significant increase in aliphatic and decrease in carboxyl OH was not observed with the microwave bio-oil. The GC/MS data are in agreement with these observations. Using catalyst 3 in [MMIM][MeOSO3], phenolic conversion was modest compared with the increase in carboxyl and decrease in aliphatic OH, the opposite trend seen using catalyst 2. This difference may be traced to the preference of catalyst 2 for CH cleavage vs. CO cleavage preferred by catalyst 3 [15]. Copper catalyst 4 showed a comparable performance for the pyrolysis bio-oil as those previously reported with lignin models [16a,b] and lignin extracts [18]. Formation of high molecular weight compounds after oxidation can likely be attributed to radical recombination. The advantages of a homogeneous catalyst system employing ionic liquids include excellent selectivity, recyclability and easy product separation. The latter two of these were considered to be limitations of conventional homogeneous catalysts. In this work we showed that the products could be easily separated by solvent fractionation, leaving the catalyst and ionic liquid in one phase ready for recycling. The base-metal (vanadium and copper) catalysts used in this work are earth abundant (non-precious) and cheaper compared to noble metal (platinum and gold) catalysts. Since ionic liquids are tunable, the water-soluble oxovanadium catalyst can be designed to carry out reactions in aqueous media. Valorization of lignin-derived bio-oils strongly depends on the price of lignin and the cost of processing using pyrolysis or microwave techniques. Upgrading bio-oils for energy applications faces a complicated challenge aggravated by the current low prices of fossil fuels. In this work we showed that aerobic oxidation of bio-oils using oxovanadium complexes oxidized some phenolic components and reduced the amount of higher MW pyrolytic lignin. It is hoped that these modification will improve the properties of lignin-derived bio-oils for polymer blending and copolymer formation [29]. This work is currently underway. coredata.dc:description: Herein, we report the aerobic oxidation of several bio-oils (pyrolysis and microwave) derived from Kraft lignin using oxovanadium complex catalyst, (HQ)2Vv(O)(O i Pr) (HQ=8-oxyquinoline) (2), ionic liquid (IL)-tagged oxovanadium complex, PF6-IL-salen-VIV(O) (3) (PF6 =hexafluorophosphate) and copper catalyst CuX/TEMPO/2,6-lutidine (4) [X=OTf, trifluoro-methanesulfonate), Cl; TEMPO=2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl]. Cleavage of some lignin linkages and reduced phenolic content were observed by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy, FT-IR and 1D/2D GC/MS analysis. Catalyst 2 oxidized chloroform extracts of the microwave bio-oil more extensively than those from the pyrolysis bio-oil although reactivity trends were similar. With catalyst 3 in [MMIM][MeOSO3], the phenolic conversion was modest compared with the increase in carboxyl and decrease in aliphatic OH groups. IR spectra were consistent with phenol oxidation to quinone-type structures. In contrast, copper catalyst 4 showed formation of high molecular weight compounds after oxidation, likely resulting from radical recombination. Comparison of reactivity between the different types of lignin-derived bio-oils is also discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic aerobic oxidation of lignin-derived bio-oils using oxovanadium and copper complex catalysts and ionic liquids
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
